description:
Coxiella endosymbiont of Ornithodoros maritimus is a bacterial species that lives in a symbiotic relationship within the soft tick Ornithodoros maritimus. O. maritimus is a species of soft tick that primarily infests seabird nests and colonies along coastal regions.

The Coxiella endosymbiont is an obligate intracellular bacterium, meaning it can only survive and reproduce within the cells of its host, in this case, the tick O. maritimus. The endosymbiont is vertically transmitted, passing from female ticks to their offspring, ensuring its continued presence in the tick population.

Genomic analyses have revealed that the Coxiella endosymbiont has a reduced genome compared to its free-living counterparts, indicative of its long-term evolutionary adaptation to the tick host. This adaptation has likely resulted in the bacterium providing certain benefits to the tick, such as nutritional supplementation or protection against pathogens, in exchange for a stable, nutrient-rich environment within the tick's cells.

The presence of this Coxiella endosymbiont is an example of the complex and often mutually beneficial relationships that can develop between bacteria and their eukaryotic hosts over evolutionary timescales.
